name: Expression
comment:
Any Expression supports basic mathematical operations like addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, power and negate.

Furthermore, any expression can be differentiated with respect to a given variable. Also expressions know how to simplify themselves.

There are different classes of expressions:

  • Literals (see math_expressions/math_expressions.Literal)

    • Number Literals (see math_expressions/math_expressions.Number)
    • Variable Literals (see math_expressions/math_expressions.Variable)
    • Vector Literals (see math_expressions/math_expressions.Vector)
    • Interval Literals (see math_expressions/math_expressions.IntervalLiteral)

  • Operators (support auto-wrapping of parameters into Literals)

    • Unary Operators (see math_expressions/math_expressions.UnaryOperator)
    • Binary Operators (see math_expressions/math_expressions.BinaryOperator)

  • Functions (see math_expressions/math_expressions.MathFunction)

    • Pre-defined Functions (see math_expressions/math_expressions.DefaultFunction)
    • Composite Functions (see math_expressions/math_expressions.CompositeFunction)
    • Custom Functions (see math_expressions/math_expressions.CustomFunction)

Pre-defined functions are math_expressions/math_expressions.Exponential, math_expressions/math_expressions.Log, math_expressions/math_expressions.Ln, nth-math_expressions/math_expressions.Root, math_expressions/math_expressions.Sqrt, math_expressions/math_expressions.Sin, math_expressions/math_expressions.Cos and math_expressions/math_expressions.Tan.

derive.name: derive
derive.comment: Derives this expression with respect to the given variable.

simplify.name: simplify
simplify.comment: Returns a simplified version of this expression. Subclasses should overwrite this method, if applicable.

evaluate.name: evaluate
evaluate.comment: Evaluates this expression according to given type and context.

toString.name: toString
toString.comment: Returns a string version of this expression. Subclasses should override this method. The output should be kept compatible with the math_expressions/math_expressions.Parser.

hashCode.name: hashCode
hashCode.comment:
Get a hash code for this object.

All objects have hash codes. Hash codes are guaranteed to be the same for objects that are equal when compared using the equality operator ==. Other than that there are no guarantees about the hash codes. They will not be consistent between runs and there are no distribution guarantees.

If a subclass overrides math_expressions/math_expressions.Expression.hashCode it should override the equality operator as well to maintain consistency.

runtimeType.name: runtimeType
runtimeType.comment: A representation of the runtime type of the object.

==.comment:
The equality operator.

The default behavior for all dart-core.Objects is to return true if and only if this and math_expressions/math_expressions.Expression.==.other are the same object.

Override this method to specify a different equality relation on a class. The overriding method must still be an equivalence relation. That is, it must be:

  • Total: It must return a boolean for all arguments. It should never throw or return null.

  • Reflexive: For all objects o, o == o must be true.

  • Symmetric: For all objects o1 and o2, o1 == o2 and o2 == o1 must either both be true, or both be false.

  • Transitive: For all objects o1, o2, and o3, if o1 == o2 and o2 == o3 are true, then o1 == o3 must be true.

The method should also be consistent over time, so equality of two objects should not change over time, or at least only change if one of the objects was modified.

If a subclass overrides the equality operator it should override the math_expressions/math_expressions.Expression.hashCode method as well to maintain consistency.

toString.name: toString
toString.comment: Returns a string representation of this object.

noSuchMethod.name: noSuchMethod
noSuchMethod.comment:
math_expressions/math_expressions.Expression.noSuchMethod is invoked when users invoke a non-existent method on an object. The name of the method and the arguments of the invocation are passed to math_expressions/math_expressions.Expression.noSuchMethod in an dart-core.Invocation. If math_expressions/math_expressions.Expression.noSuchMethod returns a value, that value becomes the result of the original invocation.

The default behavior of math_expressions/math_expressions.Expression.noSuchMethod is to throw a dart-core.NoSuchMethodError.
